results.title: History of man: how man discovers his past
results.creator_credit: McGraw-Hill Films, American Broadcasting Company and Gene Feldman
results.brief_description: Portrays the ways in which history is reconstructed by anthropologists, archaeologists, historians and others who investigate the past. Presents history as a process of reinterpretation, always subject to new evidence. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: History of football. Ep. 6
results.creator_credit: Fremantle International, Dario Pleic, Hereward Pelling and Guy Oliver
results.brief_description: Episode 6 of The History of football - or soccer as it is known in Australia. “Africa” From colonial intervention, poverty and segregation, to independence and dictatorship, this program examines Africa’s huge potential to become a successful football nation, against its continued failure to succeed at an international level. Including historical footage of key matches as well a slew of interviews with historians and sportsmen, this examination of the history of football in Africa makes for fascinating viewing. Interviews include: Roger Milla, Abedi Pele, Thomas N’kono, Neil Tovey, Pierre Kalala and Issa Hayatou. “A game for all” This episode focuses on the history of FIFA and the other powerbrokers that influence the spread of the game culturally as well as commercially, whilst documenting the start of football’s partnership with large multi-national corporations. Touches on the history of women and football with wonderful excerpt footage. Interviews include Joao Havelange, Lennart Johansson, Pele, Jack Warner, Charles Dempsey and Dwight Yorkes. “Futures” As football is still dominated by Europe and South America this episode questions where future challenges will come from at a time when soccer has gained in popularity in China, Korea, Japan, India and the Middle East. Utilising interviews and archival footage, this episode examines the impact of soccer on these nations and the machinations of popularising the sport. Interviews include Zico, Kazu Miura, Baichung Bhutia, Kunishige, Kamamoto and Hong Deok-young.

results.title: History of football. Ep. 5
results.brief_description: This six part series offers insight into the game of football, or soccer as its known in Australia. This episode (5), “The Media” and “Superstars”, examines the role of the media and the modern trend of football players as celebrities - requiring them to be media savvy and be able to withstand the pressures of fame and intense media scrutiny. Despite fame, talent and wealth however, some players have suffered the vagaries of fame, in particular Maradona, who features extensively but also George Best and Garrincha, a Brazilian hero abandoned after his career faltered. Pele by contrast has always been a media darling, showing as much acumen and skill on the field as off. Dissects the affect that television has had on the game - turning it into a lucrative, global business and the history of the relationship between the media and football. This show also examines the rise (and fall) of the popularity of football in Japan and the powerless status of Africa on the world stage. Part two: “Superstars”. Football is a team sport but great players will outshine others. This episode examines the history of football in relation to “superstars” and player migration from club to club. Since the early twentieth century this has occurred - except that now players reap the financial benefits of record transfers. This of course escalates the pressures placed on players - as Ronaldo, George Best and Maradona reveal in frank interviews. This entertaining, well-documented and informative series contains extensive footage of key historical matches as well as interviews with Alfredo di Stefano, Pele, Zinedine Zidane, Paolo Maldini, Pepi Bican, Antonio Rava, David Hill and Joao Havelange. In various languages, with English subtitles.

results.title: History of football. Ep. 4
results.brief_description: Part 4 of “The History of football”. “For club and country” This episode charts the trials and tribulations of French football, or soccer as it is known in Australia, how its developed over the years and how winning France ‘98 and Euro 2000 has helped the country to find its football identity. Also examined is the evolution of Juventus into one of the world’s “superclubs”; Dwight Yorke talks about balancing the requirements of Manchester United with Trinidad, and Sir Alex Ferguson discusses the changes he’s seen at MU - the first billion pound club. Interviews include the first ever World Cup scorer Lucien Laurent, as well as Michel Platini, Just Fontaine, Sir Bobby Charlton, Alan Shearer, Fernando Hierro, Zinedine Zidane, Aime Jacquet, Roberto Bettaga and Dino Zoff. This episode also examines the governing bodies behind football and the politics that govern the game. Addresses the club versus country debate - African players discuss conflicts of sport versus nationalism. “The Dark side”. This episode draws together events and stories that have made headline news. Tragedies that have brought communities together; a war sparked by a match, and hooliganism that has threatened the very existence of the game. Includes an interview with Sauro Toma, whose life was saved through injury when he didn’t travel to Lisbon with his Torino team-mates; and the infamous World War Two “Death match” in which players were asked to choose between victory and execution. Interviews include relatives of the Hillsborough victims, Munich air disaster survivor Bill Foulkes, and relatives of the Zambian air crash team. This well-documented and informative series contains frank interviews, extensive footage of key historical matches as well as providing an interesting insight into the history of football, and the social context of the evolution of the game.

results.title: History of football. Ep. 3
results.creator_credit: Freemantle Media, Helen Wood and Ben Miller
results.brief_description: Part 3 of a 6 part series “The History of football” (or soccer as it is known in Australia) is an informative documentary that utilises extensive archival footage and a slew of revelatory interviews with key figures (including historians, players and coaches) in order to examine various aspects of the game. “Brazil” This segment explores Brazil’s dominance of soccer, in terms of skilled players and global presence, as well as the more violent and racist elements of the sport in Brazil. Contains footage of the infamous World Cup final between Uruguay and Brazil and examines the after effects on the black players - who were blamed squarely for the loss. The arrival of Pele (aged 17) brought black pride back to many Brazilians and saw the rise of one of the world’s greatest, and most beloved, players. Another great player, Garincha (a contemporary of Pele’s) also became a figure of Brazilian pride. Current problems for football in Brazil are addressed here - poverty, elitism, corruption and the exiting of players to Europe. Interviews: Ronaldo, Zico, Didi, Pele, Zizinho, Roberto Rivelino, Socates, Carlos Alberto Parreira, Mario Zagallo, Tele Santana. “South American Superpowers” Examines the influence of South American players on soccer, and the ways in which the phenomenal success of such teams has changed the nature of football. Illuminating interviews includes an unrepentant Maradona justifying the “Hand of God” goal that knocked England out of the 1986 World Cup. Contains footage of the Uruguay team at the 1924 and 1928 Olympics, and at the 1930 World Cup. Examines the rivalries between Uruguay, Brazil and Argentina, as well as on-field violence that has marred the sport. Briefly explores the relationship between politics and football in certain countries; the problematic rise of football in Columbia and Mexico; and the circumstances surrounding the murder of Columbian player Andres Escobar. Interviews include Ceasar Luis Menotti, Jorge Valdano, Jose Sanfilippo, Alberto Spencer, Juan Schiaffino, Roque Maspoli, Alcides Ghigga, Rene Higuita, Leonel Sanshez, Carlos Caszely and Hugo Sanchez.

results.title: History of football. Ep. 2
results.brief_description: Part 2 of a 6 part series “The History of football” (or soccer as it is known in Australia) is an informative documentary that utilises extensive archival footage and a slew of revelatory interviews with key figures (including historians, players and coaches) in order to examine various aspects of the game. “Evolution of the European game” Charts the many forces that helped make soccer what it is today in a European context, via history of soccer from its British roots. Incredible footage includes the 1927, 1934 and 1938 World Cup Finals. Interviews: Ottmar Walter, Gyula Grosics, Jeno Buzanski, Sir Tom Finney, Sir Walter Winterbottom, Pepi Bican and Rava. “European Superpowers” The history of football has been peppered with outstanding teams - Real Madrid in the 1950s, the Dutch and Germans in the 1970s, Liverpool in the 1980s, Milan and the French in the 90s - all of whom have impacted significantly on the nature of the game. Includes rare footage of the 1960, 1964 and 1968 European Championships. Interviews: Alfredo di Stefano, Franciso Gento, Gianni Rivera, Giacinto Facchetti, Jimmy Johnstone, Sir Bobby Charlton, Phil Neal, Kenny Daglish, Paolo Maldini, Alan Shearer, Oliver Bierhoff, Aime Jacquet, Zinedine Zidane and Jimmy Johnstone.

results.title: History of football. Ep. 1
results.creator_credit: Freemantle Media, Hereward Pelling and Ben Miller
results.brief_description: Part 1 of a 6 part series “The History of football” (or soccer as it is known in Australia) is an informative documentary that utilises extensive archival footage and a slew of revelatory interviews with key figures (including historians, players and coaches) in order to examine various aspects of the game. “Origins” This episode draws attention to the origins of the game of football - from ancient times to the playing fields of Victorian England, emerging as a sport with global popularity. Interviews include Hugo Sanchez and Alfredo di Stefano. “Football cultures” Each nation that has embraced football has done so in unique and idiosyncratic cultural ways. This program follows football’s role within international cultures. Spotlights include: the 1998 World Cup match between US and Iran; acceptance of soccer in Iran; conflicts between Iran and Iraq, on the field and off; the history and meaning of football in Africa - where football remains a hugely popular sport, despite the frustrations of making an impact at the World Cup level. Also addresses the rise of soccer in the US where it has become one of the chosen sports among the upper classes, which has had a trickle down effect; also touches on the history of soccer in Spain. Interviews include: Luis Suarez, Carles Rexach, Jose Angel Iribar, Francisco Gento, Andoni Zubizarreta, Clive Toye, Phil Woosnam, Pele, Abedi Pele and Henry Kissinger.

Also addresses the rise of soccer in the US where it has become one of the chosen sports among the upper classes, which has had a trickle down effect; also touches on the history of soccer in Spain. Interviews include: Luis Suarez, Carles Rexach, Jose Angel Iribar, Francisco Gento, Andoni Zubizarreta, Clive Toye, Phil Woosnam, Pele, Abedi Pele and Henry Kissinger.
description_for_label: Part 1 of a 6 part series “The History of football” (or soccer as it is known in Australia) is an informative documentary that utilises extensive archival footage and a slew of revelatory interviews with key figures (including historians, players and coaches) in order to examine various aspects of the game. “Origins” This episode draws attention to the origins of the game of football - from ancient times to the playing fields of Victorian England, emerging as a sport with global popularity. Interviews include Hugo Sanchez and Alfredo di Stefano. “Football cultures” Each nation that has embraced football has done so in unique and idiosyncratic cultural ways. This program follows football’s role within international cultures. Spotlights include: the 1998 World Cup match between US and Iran; acceptance of soccer in Iran; conflicts between Iran and Iraq, on the field and off; the history and meaning of football in Africa - where football remains a hugely popular sport, despite the frustrations of making an impact at the World Cup level. Also addresses the rise of soccer in the US where it has become one of the chosen sports among the upper classes, which has had a trickle down effect; also touches on the history of soccer in Spain. Interviews include: Luis Suarez, Carles Rexach, Jose Angel Iribar, Francisco Gento, Andoni Zubizarreta, Clive Toye, Phil Woosnam, Pele, Abedi Pele and Henry Kissinger.

results.title: History of Australian surfing
results.creator_credit: Nat Young Holdings, Grant Young and Nat Young
results.brief_description: This program reminisces over the colourful sixties, when surfing was the latest fashion - bikinis, okanuis, malibus, the Delltones, Little Patty, the stomp! Performances from many of Australia’s surfing champions are presented, including Wayne Lynch, Michael Patterson, Peter Townsend, Mark Warren, Mark Richards, Simon Anderson and Rabbit Bartholomew.
